Overview

Microsoft, like any other group of one or more persons, has made many "mistakes" (only if you don't learn from them) through out its history. .Net (Framework) was, for sure, not one of them. The dream of a standardized ecosystem (runtime) for all Microsoft (Windows, to start with) things is a good one. The Wikipedia page about the .Net Framewok, tells the story that is not the purpose here. But let's put some definition in place...

What is .Net?

A software framework that allows creating software, with a single code base from a myriad of languages, interoperability between languages and that run in diferent environments. In the end, it consists of a runtime (or runtimes), called Common Language Runtime (CLR, from now on) that excutes a intermediate language (IL, from now on) byte-code, called Common Intermediate Language (CIL, from now on and formerly called Microsoft Intermediate Language, MSIL), that is the result of compiling the actual written code. CLR also provides a set of core libraries that cater for common software needs, e.g., File System operations, Networking, etc.

This framework provides an abstraction layer that allows for the same byte-code to run on different environemnts. At first, different (almost all) versions of Microsoft's own Windows operating system but, these days through .Net Core, on (almost) every operating system, including:

  • Microsft's' Windows:
    • Windows (desktop)
    • Window Mobile
    • Windows IoT
  • Linux distros:
    • Debian
    • Ubuntu
    • Fedora
    • Red Hat
    • openSUSE
  • Apple's macOS
  • With Xamarin (via the Mono Project):
    • Google's Android
    • Apple's iOS
    • Samsung's Tizen

...that is, covering almost every living operating system and device. There is an open issue on GitHub for full support on ARM processors.

Programming Languages

Although there are .Net compilers for many languages, i.e., compilers that compile a language to CIL byte-code (e.g., Phython for .Net, the defunct Visual J#, etc.), Microsoft directly maintains the compiler for these languages:

  • CIL
  • C#
  • F#
  • VB.Net

Purpose

The intent of these series is to:

  • deep dive into what .Net really is under the covers;
  • what are the diferences between the languages, not in terms of semantics or syntax but in terms of:
    • What the language compiler does (and does not) for you;
    • limitations and constraints;
    • their CIL consequences with its auto-generated clutter.
  • Language interoperability.
